CONCLUSION: No violation of Article 3 of Protocol No. 1 - Right to free elections-{general} (Article 3 of Protocol No. 1 - Vote)

TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and is currently in compulsory residence at GPE Hospital – Fidenza ( GPE ) .
CARDINAL . On DATE , after a violent family dispute , the applicant killed his wife and injured CARDINAL of his sons . He was arrested DATE .

CARDINAL . At the end of the preliminary investigation the GPE prosecution service asked for the applicant to be committed to stand trial for murder , attempted murder , ill - treatment of his family and unauthorised possession of a firearm .

CARDINAL . On DATE , under the summary procedure under which the applicant had elected to stand trial , the GPE preliminary hearings judge ( giudice dell’udienza preliminare ) found the applicant guilty of all the charges and noted that he should be sentenced to life imprisonment . However , because the summary procedure had been used , he sentenced the applicant to DATE imprisonment and a lifetime ban from public office within the meaning of LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . The judge noted that the applicant had first attempted to strangle his wife with the cable of the telephone she had used to call the police . Then , when his wife and children ran out of the flat and down the stairwell of the building , he had fired several shots at his wife at close range , and at one of his sons , who had initially been ahead of his mother but had gone back to help her .

CARDINAL . NORP In fixing the sentence the judge took into account certain aggravating circumstances , namely the fact that the applicant ’s criminal behaviour had been against his own family and had been triggered by so trifling an incident as his children having allegedly broken his mobile phone .

CARDINAL . The judge made no allowance for the fact that the applicant had no previous criminal record , an argument the applicant had relied on as a mitigating circumstance . He found that the applicant ’s attitude in denying some of his actions and blaming his family , who he claimed were guilty of rebelling against his authority , showed that he felt no remorse whatsoever .

CARDINAL . Lastly , the judge noted that according to witness statements the applicant had been responsible for other episodes of violence over DATE , such as insults , physical violence and threats against his wife and children , including with weapons .

CARDINAL . Both ORG and the applicant appealed against that judgment , and in a judgment of DATE ORG sentenced the applicant to life imprisonment , upholding the conclusions of the preliminary hearings judge as to which aggravating and mitigating circumstances should be taken into account .
CARDINAL . The applicant appealed on points of law , and in a judgment deposited with its registry on DATE ORG dismissed the appeal .

CARDINAL . Under LAW , the life sentence imposed on the applicant entailed a lifetime ban from public office , which in turn led to the permanent forfeiture of his right to vote , in conformity with section CARDINAL of Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL of DATE ( “ Decree no . CARDINAL ” – see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
CARDINAL . The applicant ’s disenfranchisement was not mentioned in the judgments against him .
CARDINAL . In application of section DATE of Decree no . CARDINAL ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) , on DATE the electoral committee deleted the applicant ’s name from the electoral roll .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged a complaint with the electoral committee . Referring to the ORG v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL ) judgment ( no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , DATE ) , amongst other authorities , he alleged that depriving him of the right to vote was incompatible with LAW No . CARDINAL to the Convention .

CARDINAL . The complaint was rejected , and on DATE the applicant lodged an appeal with ORG . He contended that the fact that the removal of his name from the electoral roll , as an automatic consequence of his life sentence and lifetime ban from public office , was incompatible with his right to vote guaranteed by LAW No . CARDINAL to the Convention .

CARDINAL . By a judgment deposited with its registry on CARDINAL DATE ORG dismissed the appeal . It pointed out that , unlike in the ORG ( no . CARDINAL ) case ( cited above ) , where every person sentenced to imprisonment was divested of the right to vote , with no assessment of the competing interests or the proportionality of the measure , in NORP law the impugned measure was applied only where the offence was punishable with a particularly heavy sentence , including life imprisonment . The court found that the automatic aspect of the application of the voting ban to any custodial sentence was lacking in the applicant ’s case .

CARDINAL . The applicant appealed on points of law , alleging , inter alia , that his disenfranchisement was a consequence of the ancillary penalty banning him from public office ( which was itself the result of the main penalty imposed on him ) . In his view the impugned ban had nothing to do with the offence committed and the courts had no power to decide to apply such a measure .

CARDINAL . In a judgment deposited with its registry on DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s appeal . First , it referred to the ORG ( no . CARDINAL ) judgment of DATE ( ORG v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL ) [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § CARDINAL , ORG CARDINALIX ) , where ORG considered that the withdrawal of voting rights in GPE “ concern[ed ] a wide range of offenders and sentences , from DATE to life and from relatively minor offences to offences of the utmost gravity ” . It then noted that in NORP law , under LAW , only those offenders sentenced to CARDINAL years’ imprisonment were deprived of the right to vote . Where the offence attracted a sentence of DATE , the disenfranchisement lasted DATE , a lifelong ban on voting being reserved for offenders sentenced to DATE and life .
CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant lodged an application with the ORG alleging , inter alia , that his life sentence had breached ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Convention .
CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE the Grand Chamber of the ORG found violations of those ORG ( see PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL ) [ ORG ] , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , CARDINAL DATE ) .

CARDINAL . NORP ’s sentence of life imprisonment is replaced by a penalty consistent with the principles set out in the present judgment , which is a sentence not exceeding thirty years’ imprisonment . ” ( see PERSON ( no . CARDINAL ) , cited above , § CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Consequently , by a judgment deposited with its registry on DATE , ORG reversed its judgment of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) , set aside the judgment of ORG of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and fixed the applicant ’s sentence at DATE imprisonment .

CARDINAL . In the NORP legal system a ban from public office is an ancillary penalty ( LAW ) which entails forfeiture of the right to vote ( Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL ) and for which express provision is made by law in connection with a series of specific offences , irrespective of the duration of the sentence imposed DATE such as embezzlement of public funds , by a public official ( peculato ) or otherwise , extortion , and market abuse ( punishable , respectively , under Articles CARDINAL , CARDINAL bis , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ) ; certain offences against the judicial system , such as perjury by a party , fraudulent expertise or interpretation , obstructing the course of justice and “ disloyal counsel ” ( consulenza infedele ) ( punishable , respectively , under LAW , CARDINAL , CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW ) ; and offences involving abuse and misuse of the powers inherent in public office ( LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Conviction for any offence punishable by imprisonment also results in the offender being banned from public office . The ban from public office may be temporary ( where the sentence is DATE or more ) or permanent ( for sentences of DATE or more and life imprisonment ) . The relevant domestic legal provisions are the following .
CARDINAL . Presidential Decree no . CARDINAL ( on the Unified Code governing the active electorate and the maintenance and revision of the electoral rolls ) reads as follows , in so far as relevant :
“ CARDINAL . The following persons shall not vote : ...
( d ) persons who have been sentenced to penalties entailing a lifetime ban from public office ...
( e ) persons under a temporary ban from public office , for the duration of that ban .
CARDINAL . Judgments in criminal cases shall entail the loss of voting rights only once they have become final . ”
“ No change may be made to the electoral rolls ... save ... :
( CARDINAL ) where the right to vote has been lost as a result of a judgment or other measure by a judicial authority . ...
( CARDINAL ) appeals against decisions to change the electoral rolls may be lodged with the relevant electoral committee within a DATE time - limit . The committee shall decide within DATE ... ”
“ The decisions of the electoral committee ... may be challenged by appeal to the appropriate ORG . ”
CARDINAL . The Criminal Code provides as follows , in so far as relevant :
“ The ban from public office may be for life or temporary .
In the event of a lifetime ban from public office , unless the law provides otherwise , the convicted person shall be deprived of :
( CARDINAL ) the right to vote or stand for election in any electoral body ( comizio elettorale ) and all other political rights . ”

“ A sentence to life imprisonment or to imprisonment for DATE shall entail a lifetime ban from public office for the convicted person ; sentencing to imprisonment for not DATE shall entail a DATE ban from public office ... ”
CARDINAL . Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Criminal Code lay down sentencing guidelines for the trial courts and read as follows :
“ Within the limits set by the law , the court shall apply the sentence at its discretion ; it shall justify its use of this discretionary power with proper reasoning .
In increasing or decreasing the sentence the court shall not overstep the statutory limits for each type of sentence , save where expressly provided for by law . ”
“ In exercising the discretionary power mentioned in DATE Article the court shall take into account the gravity of the offence , having regard to :
( CARDINAL ) the nature , type , means , object , time , place and any other attribute of the action ;
( CARDINAL ) the gravity of the harm done or the danger caused to the victim of the offence ;
( CARDINAL ) the level of intent or the degree of guilt .
The court shall also take into account the offender ’s propensity to commit crime ( capacità a delinquere ) , based on :
( CARDINAL ) the motives behind the offence ( motivi a delinquere ) and the character of the offender ( reo ) ;
( CARDINAL ) the offender ’s past criminal and judicial record and , in general , the person ’s life and conduct prior to committing the offence ;
( CARDINAL ) the offender ’s conduct at the time of , or after , the offence ;
( CARDINAL ) the offender ’s personal , family and social situation . ”
CARDINAL . Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Criminal Code provide for the rehabilitation of offenders and read as follows :
“ Rehabilitation shall terminate any ancillary penalties and other penal effect of the conviction , unless otherwise provided by law . ”
“ Rehabilitation may be granted DATE on which the main penalty has been completed or otherwise extinguished , provided that the offender has displayed consistent and genuine good conduct . ... ”
CARDINAL . Law no . CARDINAL of CARDINAL DATE provides , inter alia , for the possibility of early release . The relevant part of LAW ( CARDINAL ) reads as follows :
“ In order to facilitate reintegration into society , convicted prisoners who take part in the re - education scheme may have their sentence reduced by DATE for DATE served ... ”
CARDINAL . NORP The relevant provisions of LAW read as follows :
“ CARDINAL . All persons deprived of their liberty shall be treated with humanity and with respect for the inherent dignity of the human person .
CARDINAL . NORP The penitentiary system shall comprise treatment of prisoners the essential aim of which shall be their reformation and social rehabilitation ... ”

“ Every citizen shall have the right and the opportunity , without any of the distinctions mentioned in LAW [ race , colour , sex , language , religion , political or other opinion , national or social origin , property , birth or other status ] and without unreasonable restrictions :
( a ) To take part in the conduct of public affairs , directly or through freely chosen representatives ;

( b ) To vote and to be elected at genuine periodic elections which shall be by universal and equal suffrage and shall be held by secret ballot , guaranteeing the free expression of the will of the electors ;
( c ) To have access , on general terms of equality , to public service in his country . ”
CARDINAL . In its General Comment no . DATE ) on LAW , ORG expressed the following view :

“ CARDINAL . In their reports , GPE parties should indicate and explain the legislative provisions which would deprive citizens of their right to vote . The grounds for such deprivation should be objective and reasonable . If conviction for an offence is a basis for suspending the right to vote , the period of such suspension should be proportionate to the offence and the sentence . Persons who are deprived of liberty but who have not been convicted should not be excluded from exercising the right to vote . ”
CARDINAL . In its views on the LOC and PERSON v. GPE case ( DATE , no . DATE ) , ORG , referring to the ORG ’s judgment in ORG ( no . CARDINAL ) [ ORG ] ( cited above ) , stated :

“ CARDINAL ... ORG , whose legislation provides a blanket deprivation of the right to vote to anyone sentenced to a term of imprisonment , did not provide any arguments as to how the restrictions in this particular case would meet the criterion of reasonableness as required by the LAW . In the circumstances , the ORG concludes there has been a violation of article CARDINAL alone and in conjunction with article CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL , of the LAW ... ”
CARDINAL . DATE of ORG , under the heading “ Right to Participate in Government ” , provides :
“ CARDINAL . Every citizen shall enjoy the following rights and opportunities :
a. to take part in the conduct of public affairs , directly or through freely chosen representatives ;
b. to vote and to be elected in genuine periodic elections , which shall be by universal and equal suffrage and by secret ballot that guarantees the free expression of the will of the voters ; and
c. to have access , under general conditions of equality , to the public service of his country .

CARDINAL . The law may regulate the exercise of the rights and opportunities referred to in the preceding paragraph only on the basis of age , nationality , residence , language , education , civil and mental capacity , or sentencing by a competent court in criminal proceedings . ”

CARDINAL . This document , adopted by ORG ( “ the GPE Commission ” ) at its CARDINALst plenary session ( DATE ) and submitted to ORG of ORG on DATE , lays out the guidelines developed by the Commission concerning the circumstances in which people may be deprived of the right to vote or to stand for election . The relevant passages read as follows :
“ i. provision may be made for depriving individuals of their right to vote and to be elected , but only subject to the following cumulative conditions :
ii . it must be provided for by law ;
iii . the proportionality principle must be observed ; conditions for depriving individuals of the right to stand for election may be less strict than for disenfranchising them ;
iv . the deprivation must be based on mental incapacity or a criminal conviction for a serious offence ;
v. Furthermore , the withdrawal of political rights or finding of mental incapacity may only be imposed by express decision of a court of law . ”

CARDINAL . DATE examined in a comparative law study place no restrictions on the right of convicted prisoners to vote : GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , “ the former GPE ” and GPE .
CARDINAL . Seven GPE ( GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE ) automatically deprive all convicted prisoners serving prison sentences of the right to vote .

CARDINAL . The remaining CARDINAL member GPE ( GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE ) have adopted an intermediate approach : disenfranchisement of prisoners depends on the type of offence and/or the length of the custodial sentence . GPE ’s legislation on the subject resembles that of this group of countries .

CARDINAL . In some of the GPE in this category the decision to deprive convicted prisoners of the right to vote is left to the discretion of the criminal court ( GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE , GPE and GPE ) . In GPE and GPE , in the event of particularly serious offences disenfranchisement is applied independently of any court decision .

CARDINAL . In DATE ORG unanimously struck down a legislative provision barring all prisoners from voting ( PERSON v. GPE ( no . CARDINAL ) , ORG , DATE , vol . CARDINAL , p. CARDINAL ) . Amendments were introduced limiting the ban to prisoners serving sentences of DATE or more . ORG upheld that provision . However , on DATE ORG held by CARDINAL votes to CARDINAL , in the case of PERSON v. Attorney General of GPE ( no . CARDINAL ) , that section CARDINAL ( e ) of the DATE LAW , denying the right to vote to all persons serving sentences of DATE or more in a correctional institution , was unconstitutional as it infringed ORG CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW , which provide :
“ CARDINAL . LAW guarantees the rights and freedoms set out in it subject only to such reasonable limits prescribed by law as can be demonstrably justified in a free and democratic society . ”
“ CARDINAL . Every citizen of GPE has the right to vote in an election of members of ORG or of a legislative assembly and to be qualified for membership therein . ”

CARDINAL . The majority opinion given by PERSON considered that the right to vote was fundamental to democracy in GPE and the rule of law and could not be lightly set aside . Limits on this right required not deference , but careful examination . The majority found that the Government had failed to identify the particular problems that required denying the right to vote and that the measure did not satisfy the proportionality test , in particular as the Government had failed to establish a rational connection between the denial of the right to vote and its stated objectives of enhancing civic responsibility and respect for the rule of law and imposing appropriate punishment .

CARDINAL . The minority opinion given by PERSON found that the objectives of the measure were pressing and substantial and based upon a reasonable and rational social or political philosophy ( for further details of these opinions , particularly concerning the objectives of the impugned measure , see PERSON ( no . CARDINAL ) [ ORG ] , cited above , § § DATE ) .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG considered the application of prisoners for a declaration and orders that ORG take measures enabling them and other prisoners to register and vote while in prison . It noted that , under LAW , the right of every adult citizen to vote in elections for legislative bodies was set out in unqualified terms , and it underlined the importance of that right :

“ The universality of the franchise is important not only for nationhood and democracy . The vote of each and every citizen is a badge of dignity and personhood . Quite literally , it says that everybody counts . ”

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court found that the right to vote by its very nature imposed positive obligations upon the legislature and the executive and that LAW must be interpreted in a way that gave effect to constitutional declarations , guarantees and responsibilities . It noted that many democratic societies imposed voting disabilities on some categories of prisoners . Although there were no comparable provisions in LAW , it recognised that limitations might be imposed upon the exercise of fundamental rights , provided they were , inter alia , reasonable and justifiable .

CARDINAL . The question whether legislation barring prisoners would be justified under LAW was not raised in the proceedings and the court emphasised that the judgment was not to be read as preventing ORG from disenfranchising certain categories of prisoners . In the absence of such legislation , prisoners had the constitutional right to vote and neither ORG nor ORG had the power to disenfranchise them . It concluded that the ORG was under the obligation to make reasonable arrangements for prisoners to vote .

CARDINAL . The Constitutional Court of GPE examined whether the DATE amendment to LAW , depriving of the right to vote those prisoners serving sentences of imprisonment without the option of a fine , was compatible with LAW .
CARDINAL . ORG found the measure unconstitutional , by CARDINAL votes to CARDINAL , and ordered ORG to take the necessary steps to allow prisoners to vote in elections .

CARDINAL . Chaskalson CJ , for the majority , concluded that in a case such as this where the government sought to disenfranchise a group of its citizens and the purpose was not self - evident , there was a need for it to place sufficient information before the court to enable it to know exactly what purpose the disenfranchisement was intended to serve . Moreover , in so far as the ORG relied upon policy considerations , there should be sufficient information to enable the court to assess and evaluate the policy that was being pursued ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the judgment ) . PERSON further noted that this was a blanket exclusion aimed at every prisoner sentenced to imprisonment without the option of a fine , and that there was no information about the sort of offences concerned , the sort of persons likely to be affected and the number of persons who might lose their vote for a minor offence .

CARDINAL . Madala J , for the minority , considered that the temporary removal of the vote and its restoration upon the prisoner ’s release was in line with the ORG ’s objective of balancing individual rights and the values of society , particularly in a country like GPE with its very high crime rate ( see paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the judgment ) .
